Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the unfinished code sample taunting me. My mentor had been clear: “I want to see your progress at our next meeting. Don’t let me down.” I wanted to impress her, to prove I was serious about learning. But as I typed, my phone buzzed with a reminder—today was my deep cleaning shift. The house manager expected every corner spotless, every surface sanitized. I could already hear her voice: “No shortcuts. We have guests tomorrow.”

My mind raced. If I focused on the code, I’d fall behind on cleaning, risking complaints or even losing my job. But if I prioritized cleaning, I’d disappoint my mentor and maybe lose her trust. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, neither willing to wait. I felt torn, anxious, and guilty, knowing I couldn’t give my best to both. My hands hovered over the keyboard, but my eyes drifted to the cleaning supplies waiting in the corner, and I wondered how I could possibly choose.
